messageBody:
On 7/10/07, Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@...> wrote:
> David Saff wrote:
> > First, I accomplish what you discuss through package
> > organization: I can run test.unit.**, test.online.**, or
> > test.** to get everything.
> > This doesn't match every conceivable need, but it does match
> > every need I've had so far. Would it handle your current situation?
>
> As Cedric pointed out, this only works if a test is a member of only one
> group. As so many others do, many of my tests are annotated to be in
> multiple groups. For instance, "nightly" and "quick" and "bug" meaning
> "I want CruiseControl to run this test every night. Also, this test is
> quick (and is therefore suitable for our continuous build). Finally,
> this test illustrates a bug which is not yet fixed."

I agree your situation requires multiple groups. It also seems that
Christian's original need can be met with what's currently in the
current version of junit + cpsuite, without waiting for this
discussion to complete, so that seems worth pointing out.

> > So, questions for the community:
> >
> > 1) Should something like ClasspathSuite be incorporated into JUnit?
>
> I believe so. I certainly need functionality like that and currently
> have to go to an extension to get it. Assuming there are many other
> people in the same boat, why not build it right in?

I myself use cpsuite on enough projects that I'm very tempted to build
it in. On the other hand, Johannes has done a great job responding to
bug reports and feature requests on cpsuite: it's certainly more
mature than if we had built it ourselves and maintained it at our
current pace. We'll look at it for 4.5.

> > 2) Should something like JUnitExt's categories be
> > incorporated into JUnit?
>
> Yes, especially if it allows you to annotate a test case - and
> preferably even a test method - as being a member of multiple groupings.
>
> > 3) If yes to the above, what should the API look like?
>
> As far as the categories go, I would like to see a simple method-level
> annotation that looks like this:
>
> @TestGroups={"nightly", "quick", "bug"}

Any takers on identifying categories with classes?

@TestGroups({Nightly.class, Quick.class, Bug.class})

I'm thinking:

- auto-completion
- refactoring
- easy hook for running (just run Nightly.class to get the Nightly build)
- easy place for further customization (@BeforeClass, @AfterClass, etc)

Thanks,

David Saff
